meta.title: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia and lymphoblastic lymphoma

content:
Introduction

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and lymphoblastic lymphoma (LBL) comprise a group of hematologic malignancies involving early lymphoid precursor cells.  ALL and LBL are the most common types of cancer in children.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Hematologic cell proliferation and differentiation is normally a highly regulated process.  However, early lymphoid precursor cells can acquire genetic changes that drive proliferation but impair differentiation, resulting in a lymphoblastic malignancy.  ALL and LBL are different clinical presentations that share this common disease origin.  In ALL, the bone marrow and peripheral blood are involved; in LBL, the malignancy primarily involves a mass (eg, thymic mass) with minimal bone marrow involvement.  Both presentations may have overlapping features (eg, LBL that progresses to the bone marrow), and here the term ALL will be used to refer to ALL and LBL jointly.



In ALL, the acquisition of serial genetic changes has the net result of uncontrolled clonal proliferation of early lymphoid precursor cells (ie, lymphoblasts) that lack the ability to differentiate into mature cells.  The lymphoblasts accumulate at the site of proliferation, leading to signs and symptoms of disease (eg, bone marrow causing cytopenias, thymus causing respiratory distress).



Risk factors for ALL include:



  • Age:  primarily occurs in childhood, with peak incidence at age 2-5
  • Genetic disorders:  certain underlying genetic syndromes (eg, Down syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1)
  • Family history:  siblings with ALL increase an individual's risk.  The concordance rate for identical twins is nearly 100%.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of ALL varies, depending on the type of cell and site of proliferation.  B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) represents 80%-85% of cases and typically presents in early childhood, when production of B cells in the bone marrow peaks.  Proliferating lymphoblasts interfere with normal hematopoiesis, and patients develop signs and symptoms of cytopenias, including:



  • Anemia:  fatigue, pallor, decreased exercise tolerance
  • Neutropenia:  increased risk for opportunistic infections (eg, candidiasis, aspergillosis); patients can present with recurrent fever and/or night sweats
  • Thrombocytopenia:  bruising or bleeding complications (eg, gingival bleeding, petechiae (
    image 1
    )).


In addition, patients often develop long bone pain (eg, femur, tibia) as proliferating lymphoblasts expand the bone marrow.  The dull pain is often more noticeable at night and can manifest as general irritability and, in toddlers, a refusal to walk.



In contrast to B-ALL, T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) represents 15%-20% of cases and typically presents in adolescence, when production of T cells in the thymus peaks.  This condition often presents with a mediastinal mass that compresses surrounding structures, including the airway (causing dyspnea) and superior vena cava (causing SVC syndrome (

Superior vena cava syndrome
)).  Pleural effusions are common due to inflammation from tumor growth and cytokine release.



As the disease progresses, patients with ALL can develop symptoms associated with infiltration and proliferation of lymphoblasts beyond the bone marrow and peripheral blood, including:



  • Liver/spleen:  causes organomegaly, which can lead to poor appetite, weight loss, and/or abdominal pain
  • Lymph nodes:  causes enlarged, nontender, firm lymph nodes
  • CNS:  causes increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, vomiting), cranial nerve palsies, and/or seizures
  • Testicles:  causes unilateral, painless testicular enlargement

Diagnosis



Because the initial presentation of ALL can be nonspecific (eg, fever, fatigue, bone pain), a high degree of suspicion is required, especially when the symptoms are persistent or recurrent.  In cases of suspected ALL, the initial laboratory evaluation includes:



  • Complete blood count and peripheral smear:  typically shows anemia and thrombocytopenia.  The white blood cell (WBC) count is often initially low due to lymphoblastic interference with normal WBC production.  As the disease progresses, lymphoblasts accumulate in the bone marrow and spill into the peripheral blood, resulting in a normal or elevated WBC count (ie, >50,000/mm3 confers a worse prognosis).  In addition, lymphoblasts can be visualized on peripheral smear.
  • Lactate dehydrogenase:  often elevated due to increased cell turnover.
  • Serum chemistries:  can be normal or consistent with tumor lysis syndrome, a complication of rapid cell lysis in which phosphate, potassium, and uric acid are released into systemic circulation.  Electrolyte derangements can lead to acute kidney injury and dysrhythmias.

Laboratory evaluation



Diagnosis can be confirmed by identification of lymphoblasts based on morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular features.

Cell morphology



Cell sampling for morphological assessment may be obtained from various sources (eg, bone marrow, lymph node).  The presence of an increased population (ie, at least 20%) of uniform-appearing blastsâ€”characterized by large nuclei with dispersed chromatin, scant cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoliâ€”is suggestive of clonal proliferation and consistent with leukemia (

image 2
).

Flow cytometry



Immunophenotyping identifies cell surface markers specific to lymphoid blasts (

image 3
).



  • Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT):  a DNA polymerase involved in the diversification of antigen receptors during early B-cell and T-cell maturation and is only expressed on the cell surface of lymphoid progenitor cells.  The presence of TdT differentiates lymphoblasts from mature lymphocytes.
  • Lymphoblasts can be further differentiated by cell surface markers specific to B cells or T cells:


  • B lymphoblasts:  CD10, CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a (typically CDs â‰¥10)
  • T lymphoblasts:  CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8 (typically CDs <10)

Cytogenetic and molecular studies



Cytogenetic and molecular studies identify specific chromosomal abnormalities and mutations associated with ALL, which can help with risk stratification for management.

Additional workup



Additional workup to consider in cases of suspected ALL includes:



  • Lumbar puncture:  to screen for lymphoblastic infiltration of the cerebrospinal fluid
  • Chest imaging:  to evaluate for the presence of a mediastinal mass, especially prior to anesthesia (due to increased risk for airway obstruction)

Differential diagnosis



Because the initial presentation of ALL can be nonspecific, the differential diagnosis is broad:

Cytopenias



  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML):  a type of acute leukemia that involves myeloid (not lymphoid) precursors.  It can present similarly with pancytopenia and bone pain; however, lymphadenopathy is less common since lymphoid cells are not involved.  AML can be distinguished from ALL through immunophenotyping, as myeloid blasts express different cell surface markers (eg, myeloperoxidase, CD33).  Auer rods (needle-like inclusions in the cytoplasm) are also specific for AML (
    image 4
    ).
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML):  can progress to blast crisis, the most aggressive phase of disease.  Blast crisis can be indistinguishable from ALL as it presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, and symptoms of cytopenias.  In addition, the BCR::ABL1 fusion gene can occur in de novo ALL.  However, the presence of BCR::ABL1 in mature lymphoid cells is a hallmark of CML, distinguishing it from de novo ALL with BCR::ABL1.
  • Burkitt lymphoma:  involves malignant mature B cells and presents with cytopenias from bone marrow failure with lymphadenopathy.  Similar to B-ALL, CD19 is expressed; however, because the malignant cell is a mature B cell, TdT is not expressed, which distinguishes Burkitt lymphoma from ALL.
  • Aplastic anemia:  characterized by pancytopenia and hypocellular bone marrow. It typically presents with symptoms related to pancytopenia, similar to ALL.  Bone marrow biopsy shows markedly decreased hematopoietic cells, increased fat cells, and absent malignant cells.
  • Viral infections:  Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus can cause pancytopenia, fever, fatigue, and hepatosplenomegaly.  Peripheral smear shows circulating atypical lymphocytes (
    image 5
    ), not lymphoid blasts.
  • Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP):  characterized by bruising and petechiae due to isolated low platelet count.  Pancytopenia and organomegaly are not expected.

Bone pain



  • Growing pains:  self-limited, episodic, lower-extremity pain that usually occurs in young children at night and does not affect normal function (eg, ambulation).  In contrast, bone pain in ALL tends to be constant and progressive, often interfering with normal function and may be associated with systemic symptoms.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus:  can present with joint pain, fever, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly.  Blast cells are not seen on peripheral smear.
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis:  characterized by joint pain, swelling, and morning stiffness.  Patients typically have leukocytosis and reactive thrombocytosis (rather than panycytopenia).

Chest mass



Other causes of chest mass (thymoma, Hodgkin disease) can be distinguished by certain clinical features.  Thymomas tend to occur in patients age >40 and do not cause pancytopenia.  Hodgkin disease is characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells and a unique immunophenotype (positive CD15 and CD30) (

Classic Hodgkin lymphoma CHL
).

Management



Management of ALL involves chemotherapy, which is guided by risk stratification, accounting for the patient's age (eg, <1 or >10 years is associated with worse prognosis), presenting WBC count (eg, >50,000/mm3 is associated with worse prognosis, likely due to more advanced disease), disease features (eg, immunophenotype, genetic findings), and response.  The phases of therapy include:



  • Induction phase involves systemic treatment with a combination of vincristine, asparaginase, a glucocorticoid, and CNS-directed intrathecal chemotherapy.  An anthracycline and/or targeted agent may also be added depending on disease features (eg, tyrosine kinase inhibitor if BCR::ABL1 is present).  The goal of the induction phase is to achieve remission, a state in which there are no detectable leukemia cells.
  • Consolidation phase for patients who achieve remission (ie, additional chemotherapy with CNS-directed treatment) to prevent relapse.
  • Maintenance phase, which helps maintain remission and typically lasts 2-3 years.


Allogeneic stem cell transplantation may be considered for patients who have very-high-risk features (eg, failed induction, persistent MRD after induction phase).



Patients with ALL are at high risk for complications (eg, tumor lysis syndrome) and should be monitored accordingly.  In general, patients with ALL require supportive care with transfusions (due to prolonged or worsening pancytopenia), nutritional support, and infection prevention (eg, antimicrobial prophylaxis).

Prognosis



With conventional treatment protocols, the prognosis for ALL is favorable; the 5-year overall survival rate is ~90%.  Predictors of a favorable prognosis include age 1-10 and initial WBC count <50,000/mm3 for patients with B-ALL.  However, the most significant prognostic factor is the patient's response to therapy (eg, remission status at the end of induction for B-ALL).

Summary



Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and lymphoblastic lymphoma (LBL) (
